I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.    The Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) aims to achieve 
economic growth, reduce poverty, and graduate from its least-developed country status by 2020. 
The 2004–2006 Country Strategy and Planning (CSP)1 update reaffirms the priority given to 
strengthening  governance  through  policy  and  institutional  development  as  key  to  poverty 
reduction in the Lao PDR. A critical component in strengthening governance is development of a 
legal system that gives all citizens fair access to justice. Lack of an efficient and effective legal 
system not only constrains improvement in the country’s overall governance, but also limits the 
potential for greater foreign investment inflows and private sector development.  
 
2.    The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  supported  the  establishment  of  a  commercial 
division of the civil court to deal with defaulting borrowers.2 Necessary rules of the court have 
been adopted, and judges and enforcement officers assigned to commercial divisions have 
undergone initial training. All 18 provinces have established a commercial division of the civil 
court and have begun hearing cases. However, there is substantial scope for continued training 
of court officials3 and court judgment enforcement officers, given their inexperience and lack of 
knowledge of commercial/financial activities. The Government has requested ADB to provide 
technical assistance (TA)4 that will continue to support the resolution of commercial disputes, 
including strengthening mediation and arbitration processes and commercial law-related court 
proceedings and will ensure fair and transparent judgments and speedy enforcement of court 
decisions on defaulting financial/commercial transactions. Fully operationalizing the nascent 
secured transactions registry will augment the legal system in resolving financial/commercial 
disputes. The Fact-Finding Mission fielded to Vientiane, Lao PDR during 26–30 September 
2005 discussed the TA scope and implementation arrangements. The Government concurred 
on  the  TA  paper,  including  the  purpose,  scope,  implementation,  cost  and  financing 
arrangements. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Government strives to improve its legal system and recently promulgated a number 
of new laws (on Government, National Assembly, Local Administration, Land, Enforcement of 
Judicial Decisions, People’s Court, and People’s Judiciary Authority), but weak governance and 
capacity continue to pose serious constraints. Lack of a reliable legal system for resolving 
disputes arising from financial/commercial activities is a major obstacle in attracting foreign 
direct investment and promoting private sector development. In particular, implications have 
been significant for the financial sector, where risks for commercial lending have been assessed 
as being exceptionally high due to deficiencies in the legal system, prohibiting expansion of 
bank lending. The ongoing Loan 1946-LAO (SF): Banking Sector Reform Program (BSRP)5 has 
a component to mobilize the judiciary to apply a strengthened legal system and for the Bank of 
the Lao PDR (BOL) to use an effective prudential system to bring failed borrowers, strategic 
defaulters, and unsound banks to account. 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2003. Country Strategy and Program (2004–2006): Lao People’s Democratic Republic. Manila.  
2  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Strengthening Governance for 
Banking Sector Reform. Manila (TA 4002-LAO, attached to Banking Sector Reform Program with the objective of 
supporting implementation of the Program, includes a component to support legal and judicial strengthening). The 
TA was approved on 28 November for $900,000. 
3  Court officials include judges and court registry staff. 
4  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 11 November 2005.   
5  On 28 November 2002, the ADB Board approved Loan 1946-LAO (SF): Banking Sector Reform Program for $15 
million. The Program's objective is to support the Government’s efforts to foster efficient financial intermediation 
and ensure a sound banking system capable of supporting growth and rural outreach.

2   
4.  With the support of the International Monetary Fund, BOL regulations have gradually 
been upgraded. BOL now conducts regular off-site monitoring and on-site examinations on 
banks operating in the Lao PDR. Under the BSRP, ADB supported the establishment of a 
commercial division of the civil court to deal with defaulting borrowers (footnote 1). Preliminary 
rules  of  court  have  been  adopted,  and  judges  and  enforcement  officers  assigned  to  the 
commercial division of the court have undergone initial training. The first commercial division of 
the civil court was established in the civil chamber of the Vientiane municipality court on 1 July 
2003. Since then, all 18 provinces have established a commercial division and have begun 
hearing  cases.  However,  there  is  substantial  scope  for  continued  training  of  judges  and 
enforcement  officers,  given  their  limited  experience  and  lack  of  knowledge  of 
commercial/financial activities.   
 
5.  Despite the enactment of the Law on Enforcement of Judicial Decisions in May 2004, 
judgment enforcement remains one of the most problematic areas of the country’s legal system. 
The Government established the Division of Court for Judgment Execution in the Ministry of 
Justice (MOJ), but the division still lacks the capacity to monitor progress in enforcing judgment, 
particularly at the provincial level. Constant delays and frequent mismanagement in judgment 
enforcement for settling commercial/financial disputes have been disruptive and are the cause 
of confusion in the marketplace. To enable efficient and effective enforcement of court judgment, 
there is a need for establishing clear and standardized procedures to be adopted at all levels of 
judgment enforcement, continued training for enforcement officers, and awareness building 
among the public.  
 
6.  In liquidating assets held as loan collateral, inexperience and lack of an established 
procedure have resulted in unfair pricing and ambiguous transactions, further eroding public 
confidence in the newly established system. For auctioning assets held as collateral, there 
needs to be a clear set of procedures that ensure transparency and fairness to all parties 
concerned. The Notary Office created by MOJ in 2000 in accordance with the law on notaries is 
currently unable to complete the required tasks of certifying or witnessing the accuracy of sales, 
loans,  other  business-related  contracts,  testimonies,  copies  of  documents,  signatures,  and 
translations. Clearly there is a need to now review and assess the various components of the 
legal system that impede commercial dispute resolution. A well-sequenced plan needs to be 
formulated  to  ensure  that  the  commercial  division  of  the  court  functions  as  expected  and 
provides  the  legal  means  for  expeditious  resolution  of  defaulting  financial  and commercial 
transactions. 
 
7.  Insufficient  capacity  of  the  beneficiaries  of  the  legal  system  has  also  hindered  the 
commercial division from functioning effectively. Requirements for standard loan and other 
commercial transaction documentation and knowledge of the legal procedures are lacking, 
particularly the state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs). Bank operations suffer from sizable 
nonperforming loans (NPLs) with little prospects for resolution. The SOCBs have no legal 
departments and lack staff with basic legal background or training. Supporting capacity building 
of the beneficiaries of the legal system, the SOCBs in particular, will improve governance in the 
financial/commercial  system,  consistent  with  the  thrust  of  Loan  1946-LAO  (footnote  4)  for 
financial sector development. 
 
8.  The  Government  has  also  established  the  Office  of  Economic  Dispute  Resolution 
(OEDR)6 under MOJ in Vientiane, with branches in Savannakhet and Luang Prabang, for 
mediation and arbitration in cases of economic disputes arising primarily from breaches of 
                                                 
6  Operating under Decree106/PM on the resolution of economic disputes, dated 17 July 1994 and Arbitration Law 
2005.

3
contracts.  Given  that  informal  dispute  resolution  mechanisms  are  the  preferred  means  for 
dispute  resolution  in  the  country,  the  potential  role  of  the  OEDR  is  significant.  With  the 
promulgation  of  the  Arbitration  Act  in  August  2005,  the  time  and  expenses  related  to 
commercial/financial  dispute  resolution  may  be  reduced  considerably  by  enhancing  the 
operations of OEDR. The mediators and arbitrators also will benefit from additional training on 
newly issued commercial/financial laws and regulations, and OEDR’s function and use could be 
better promoted in the private sector, raising awareness of the OEDR as a quick and viable 
alternative to court proceedings.   
 
9.  The Secured Transactions Law and its implementing decree are the major components 
of financial governance and are fundamental in mobilizing domestic credit and international 
investment in Lao PDR. The implementation of the secured transactions regime, including the 
Secured Transactions Law, its Decree, and the secured transactions registry, would create an 
enabling environment for private financing, especially at a time when Lao PDR is seeking to join 
the World Trade Organization (WTO)7, and is in the process of initiating the Nam Theun 2 
hydroelectric project. The revised and upgraded Secured Transactions Law was submitted to 
and approved by the National Assembly on 20 May 2005. The draft implementing decree will be 
developed  in  February  2006.  To  ensure  the  widespread  utilization  of  the  Law,  and  the 
development  of  a  secured  transactions  regime,  supporting  capacity  building  and  training 
seminars would be required for the financial, commercial, and judicial sectors in Lao PDR. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA aims to strengthen the formal and informal mechanisms for commercial dispute 
resolution so as to ensure predictable, transparent, and speedy resolution supported, where 
needed, by court judgments effectively enforced. A reliable system for commercial dispute 
resolution in accordance with the rule of law and a fully operationalized secured transactions 
registry will reduce the risk of doing business in the Lao PDR and thereby facilitate foreign direct 
investment and private sector development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA comprises four components: 
 
(i)  The first component will review current operations of the commercial division of 
the court to identify key impediments hindering its effective functioning. The study 
will  recommend  specific  and  practical  measures  for  resolving  the  identified 
impediments.  The  recommendations  will  be  sequenced  and  prioritized,  and 
contain  cost  estimates.  The  first  phase  of  the  recommendations,  which  will 
include  capacity  building  for  the  Notary  Public  Office  and  enhancement  of 
enforcement procedures including clarifying procedures for auctioning of assets 
held as collateral, will be completed under the TA. This component will also 
review  and  develop  the  self-help  procedures  and  arbitration  and  mediation 
alternatives available to disputing parties in the first instance, prior to recourse to 
the courts. A public awareness program will be developed to assist the private 
sector to better understand and use the dispute resolution mechanisms and 
litigation rights available to them.  
                                                 
7   Four GMS countries––Cambodia, PRC, Myanmar, and Thailand––are now members of WTO, with Lao PDR and 
Viet Nam in the process of negotiating WTO membership.

4   
(ii)  The second component will undertake further capacity building for the judiciary 
and  trainers  by  conducting  the  next  training  series  for  court  officials  and 
enforcement  officers  assigned  to  the  commercial  division  of  the  court.  The 
training program will build on the three series of training completed under TA 
4002-LAO  (footnote  1).  Emphasis  will  be  on  court  proceedings  and  case 
management using actual cases filed at the commercial division of the court, 
particularly those related to defaulting financial and commercial transactions. The 
training  will  extend  to  related  commercial  dealings  and  will  give  priority  to 
developing local training expertise. 
(iii)  The third component will operationalize a secured transactions regime in Lao 
PDR  and  thus  create  an  enabling  environment  to  increase  availability, 
affordability, and transparency of credit access, as well as facilitate domestic and 
cross-border  investment.  The  main  output  will  be  an  operational  secured 
transactions  registry  and  capacity  building  modules  to  support  the 
implementation of the secured transactions regime. The establishment of the 
secured transactions registry and capacity building modules will also seek to 
involve  other  funding  agencies  and  thus  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the 
training modules outside the major urban areas of Luang Prabang, Pakse, and 
Vientiane. 
(iv)  The final component will support the two SOCBs in (a) setting up or enhancing 
the legal departments to implement standard loan and commercial transaction 
documentation, the dispute resolution mechanisms, and for filing NPL cases for 
court decisions; and (b) supporting the internal asset management units (work-
out units) for resolution of NPLs.  
 
12.  Capacity building efforts rely heavily on adequate understanding of the current state of 
affairs, operational constraints, and appropriately matching the level of training materials to the 
beneficiaries. The review of the current operations of the commercial division of the court in the 
first component is expected to enable the consultants to become sufficiently aware of the 
current training needs and reduce the risk of preparing training materials unsuitable for the Lao 
PDR. Furthermore, successful implementation of the TA assumes that judges and enforcement 
officers assigned to the commercial divisions of the court are made available for training. Both 
People’s Supreme Court and MOJ have given their assurances that all judges and enforcement 
officers assigned to the commercial division will be made available for all training sessions to be 
conducted under the TA.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $780,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $650,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost of 
$525,000 and $125,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis,  $500,000  by  ADB's  TA  funding  program  and  $150,000  by  the  Government  of 
Luxembourg, with the latter amount administered by ADB. The Government will finance the 
balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $130,000, through the provision of counterpart 
staff salaries, office accommodation and transport, support services, and the facilitation of 
consultations. Appendix 2 provides details of the cost estimates and financing plan.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  MOJ will be the Executing Agency. Implementing agencies (IAs) will be the Ministry of 
Finance, the People’s Supreme Court, BOL, Banque pour le Commerce Exterieur Lao (BCEL), 
and Lao Development Bank (LDB). They will provide office space, counterpart staff, and other

5
support services to the consultants. MOJ and People’s Supreme Court will ensure that relevant 
enforcement officers and judges are freed from their daily tasks to attend the training sessions. 
MOJ and the IAs will be responsible for (i) selecting of the trainers for training; (ii) monitoring 
that the quality of the training materials produced under the TA is appropriate for the operating 
environment of the Lao PDR, together with ADB; and (iii) continuing the training program 
following TA completion. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 10 months, from May 2006 to March 2007, and will 
require the service of six international (19.5 person-months) and six domestic consultants (25 
person-months). The international consultants (person-months are in parentheses) comprise 
governance and judicial training expert-team leader (4), an enforcement expert (2), a mediation 
and  arbitration  expert  (2),  legal  expert  (3),  secured  transactions  expert  (5)  and  an  NPL 
resolution (legal) expert (3.5). The domestic consultants will have expertise in governance and 
judicial  training  (5),  enforcement  (2.5),  mediation  and  arbitration  (2.5),  legal  (4),  secured 
transactions (6), and NPL resolution (5). All consultants will work intermittently over the TA 
implementation period.  
 
16.  As outlined in the terms of reference (Appendix 3), the consultant team will produce 
various reports each of which will be discussed at the tripartite meetings. Aside from the training 
materials  under  the  responsibility of  each  international consultant,  the  team  leader  will be 
responsible for submitting the inception report to MOJ and IAs, and ADB, which will include a 
diagnostic study and implementation plan for the capacity-building exercise, approximately 2 
weeks after the international consultants are fielded. A midterm report will be prepared after 
completing the first round of training sessions. A final report, containing recommendations for 
further actions by the Government and specific areas requiring continued technical assistance, 
will be prepared 2 weeks before completion of the TA.  
 
17.  The consultants will be engaged through a firm following the quality- and cost-based 
selection  process  and  using  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  The  consultant  team  will  be 
selected according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements 
satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  of  consultants.  All  procurement  under  the  TA  will  be  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Various training seminars and workshops 
will  be  held  to  encourage  participatory  discussions  for  improving  court  proceedings  at  the 
commercial division of the civil court and judgment enforcement, and for building the capacity of 
all staff levels within the relevant government agencies and SOCBs. There will also be close 
coordination  during  TA  implementation  with  external  funding  agencies  involved  in  judicial 
reforms. The final report of the TA and all training materials produced will be disseminated to all 
stakeholders. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $150,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Luxembourg, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of the 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Promoting Governance in Financial Transactions, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Governance and Judicial Training Expert (international, 4 person-months over 8 
months) 
 
1.  The consultant should have (i) extensive experience and expertise, in commercial litigation 
and court procedures; (ii) the ability to interact with local authorities to build trust and a sense of 
ownership of action programs; (iii) experience in training and coaching local counterparts on details 
relating to legal and judicial practice; and (iv) an appreciation of regional culture. Previous work in 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) will be favorably considered. As team leader, the 
expert  will  have  excellent  communication  and  team-building  skills,  monitor  progress  in  all 
components of the TA, ensure effective coordination with all relevant aid agencies in the field, and 
be responsible for submitting the inception, midterm, and final TA reports.  
 
2.  The major tasks include (i) managing the legal components of the TA, including supervising 
and coordinating (a) other legal consultants’ activities with relevant implementing agencies (IAs), 
(b) resource persons, and (c) other personnel who will assist in implementing and monitoring 
project  activities;  (ii)  assisting  the  People’s  Supreme  Court  to  (a)  draft  specialized  rules  of 
procedures and directions for the commercial division of the civil court and develop mechanisms to 
implement those rules, including determining resource requirements; (b) draft relevant sections of 
the Laos Bench book concerning specialized rules; and (c) prepare an overview of the division of 
responsibilities between the People's Supreme Court and the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) following 
their formal separation, and recommendations and practical solutions to implement the separation 
with  minimal  budgetary  and  other  resource  implications;  (iii)  designing  a  comprehensive 
commercial law program and action plan of judicial and related parties’ capacity building and 
conduct training, based on the training undertaken under TA 4002,1 comprising (a) judgment 
writing, issue identification, case analysis; (b) mediation training for dispute settlement involving 
major  commercial  laws;  (c)  general  training  in  case  management  of  commercial  transaction 
matters and reduction of delay for at least 15 specialized commercial judges; (d) general training in 
case management of commercial transaction matters; and (e) overview of enforcement procedures; 
(iv) preparing manuals and materials to support ongoing training by Judicial Training Institute staff; 
(v) Advise other consultants on current commercial law and developments; (vi) working with the 
Notary  Public  Office  and  Prosecutors  Office  to  coordinate  training  for  staff  specializing  in 
commercial  contracts  including  such  staff  in  the  judicial  training  sessions;  where  possible, 
coordinating  with  consultants  from  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  and  Japan 
International  Cooperation  Agency;  (vii)  coordinating  the  resource  persons  who  will  assist, 
particularly in training specialized judges, court staff, and enforcement officers; (viii) Identify and 
coordinate with stakeholders such as Law Bar Associations and Courts on the involvement of other 
international agencies to support the work being undertaken; and (ix) preparing and submitting a 
final report on achievements under the TA and recommend follow-up actions. 
 
2.  Legal Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
 
3.  The  legal  expert  is  required  to  have  profound  knowledge  and  experiences  on  the 
implementation of a secured transactions regime in a small developing and transition economy. 
The legal expert will take primary responsibility in (i) ensuring that the action plan to establish the 
secured transactions registry is adopted by the Government through the Ministry of Finance, 
coordinating  with  the  secured  transactions  registry  expert  to  operationalize  the  secured 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Strengthening Governance for Banking 
Sector Reform. Manila (TA4002-Lao, attached to Banking Sector Reform Program with the objective of supporting 
implementation of the Program, includes a component to support legal and judicial strengthening). The TA was 
approved on 28 November for $900,000.

10  Appendix 3 
transactions registry; and (ii) coordinating with the international and domestic consultants to raise 
the awareness and build the capacity for effective use of the secured transactions registry. In 
particular, the expert will be responsible for (i) overseeing the design of the secured transactions 
registry and prepare an action plan for implementation; (ii) implementing the secured transactions 
implementing decree that will also provide for specific reference to the utilization of the secured 
transactions registry and the legal rights of users; (iii)  developing a series of training modules and 
workshop programs to ensure awareness raising and training of commercial judges, public sector 
officials, and the private sector (SMEs, banks, lawyers, accountants, NGOs), with the secured 
transactions expert and the domestic consultants, on the upgraded Secured Transactions Law and 
the utilization of the registry; and (iv) reviewing and recommending revisions to the Bankruptcy Law, 
Enterprise Law, Tax Law, Investment Law, and Contract Law to ensure adequate cross-reference 
between these laws and the Secured Transactions Law. 
 
3.  Mediation and Arbitration Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
 
4.  The  consultant  should  have  (i)  extensive  experience  and  expertise  in  mediation  and 
arbitration, (ii) the ability to interact with local authorities so as to build trust and a sense of 
ownership of action programs, (iii) experience in training and coaching local counterparts on key 
elements  and  technical  details  relating  to  mediation  and  arbitration  practices,  and  (iv)  an 
appreciation of regional culture. Previous work in the Lao PDR will be favorably considered. 
 
5.  The expert will be responsible for (i) developing a manual of procedures and checklists for 
mediators and arbitrators undertaking commercial dispute resolution based on the Arbitration Law 
and existing operations of the Office of Economic Dispute Resolution (OEDR); (ii) guiding the 
approval process for the manual, providing support and technical expertise to OEDR as needed; (iii) 
drafting legal instruments including ministerial orders or directions to support the implementation of 
the Arbitration Law; (iv) designing and introducing for mediators and arbitrators a comprehensive 
capacity building/training program on commercial dispute resolution matters, including preparation 
of  materials  to  support  ongoing  training  by  OEDR  staff  in  provincial  regions;  (iv)  conducting 
mediation and arbitration training for specialized commercial law judges in coordination with the 
governance and judicial training expert; (v) conducting basic mediation and arbitration training for 
staff of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) in coordination with the Nonperforming loan (NPL) 
Resolution Expert, and in particular for self-help mechanisms; (vi) working with OEDR staff to 
conduct a workshop to raise public awareness of available mediation and arbitration mechanisms, 
particularly  among  the  business  community;  (vi)  preparing  and  submitting  a  final  report  on 
achievements under the TA and recommend follow-up actions. 
 
4.  Enforcement Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
 
6.  The  consultant  should  have  (i)  extensive  experience  and  expertise  in  judgment 
enforcement procedures, (ii) the ability to interact with local authorities so as to build trust and a 
sense of ownership of action programs; (iii) experience in training and coaching local counterparts 
on  key  elements  and  technical  details  relating  to  court  enforcement  practices;  and  (iv)  an 
appreciation of regional culture. Previous work in the Lao PDR will be favorably considered. 
 
7.  The major tasks will include (i) drafting of relevant implementation regulations and develop 
a manual of procedures, including auction procedures, and checklists for enforcement officers 
responsible for enforcing judgments of the commercial division based on the Enforcement of Court 
Judgments Law and existing operations of the MOJ’s Enforcement Department; (ii) guiding the 
approval process for the manual,  providing  support and technical expertise to MOJ’s Enforcement

Appendix 3  11 
Department; (iii) drafting of legal instruments including ministerial orders or directions to support 
the implementation of the Enforcement of Court Judgments Law; (iv) designing and introducing a 
comprehensive capacity building/training program for enforcement officers, including materials to 
support ongoing training by MOJ staff in provincial regions; (v) conducting training on enforcement 
issues for specialized commercial law judges; (vi) conducting basic training on enforcement issues 
for SOCB staff; (vii) working with MOJ staff to conduct a workshop to raise public awareness of 
available  enforcement  mechanisms,  particularly  among  the  business  community;  and  (viii) 
preparing and submitting a final report on achievements under the TA and recommend follow-up 
actions.  
 
5.  Secured Transactions Expert (international, 5 person-months) 
 
8.   The  secured  transactions  expert  will  have  proven  experience  in  the  developing  of 
computerized registries either in the field of taxation or specifically, secured transactions, in a small, 
developing, or transition economy. The expert will be required to assess the existing business 
processes in Lao PDR and adapt the secured transactions registry to (i) reflect the requirements of 
Lao stakeholders, (ii) ensure the sustainability of the registry via demand-based fee structure, (iii) 
upgrade  the  registry  through  user-fee  account  subject  to  independent  audit.  The  expert  will 
coordinate with the international legal expert/team leader, and the domestic consultants on the 
implementation of training workshops to stakeholders.  
 
9.  In particular, the expert will be responsible for (i) reviewing the required characteristics of 
the secured transactions registry and the costs-benefits of a paper-based versus digital registry; (ii) 
undertaking a consultative workshop with stakeholders; (iii) developing the action plan for secured 
transactions  registry  development  and  submit  to  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  for  approval;  (iv) 
identifying a secure office in Government to establish the registry; (v) identifying and training the 
registry  staff;  (vi)  submitting  training  manuals  to  the  Government,  Lao  National  Chamber  of 
Commerce  and  Industry  and  facilitate  training  of  trainers  program;  and  (vii)  developing  and 
undertaking awareness raising workshops on utilization of the secured transactions registry by all 
stakeholders. 
 
6.  NPL Resolution (Legal) Expert (international, 3.5 person-months) 
 
10.  The expert will (i) have a legal and/or banking sector background and comprehensive 
understanding of the legal and administrative procedures required for resolving NPLs; (ii) be a 
practical implementer, trainer, and mentor, with hands-on experience and successful track record 
in leading sizable NPL resolutions, in both developed and developing economies; and (iii) be 
capable of advising senior government officials on resolving NPLs.  
 
11.  Before going into the field, the expert will acquire understanding of the current legal regime 
in the Lao PDR, the stage of financial and economic development, and activities undertaken under 
ADB’s Banking Sector Reform Program.2 The expert will be responsible for the following activities: 
(i)  Assess the issues impeding progress in NPL resolution at the three SOCBs3 and 
formulate a tactical plan for accelerating NPL resolution considering (a) the targets 
for NPL resolution set by the three SOCBs, and (b) activities already undertaken. 
Discuss  the  plan  with  (a)  bank  management,  (b)  international banking  advisors  
                                                 
2  On 28 November 2002, the ADB Board approved Loan 1946-LAO (SF): Banking Sector Reform Program for $15 
million. The Program's objective is to support the Government’s efforts to foster efficient financial intermediation and 
ensure a sound banking system capable of supporting growth and rural outreach. 
3  Banque pour le Commerce Exterieur Lao, Lao Development Bank, and Agriculture Promotion Bank.

12  Appendix 3 
(IBAs) of the three SOCBs, and (iii) Asian Development Bank (ADB) and finalize the 
plan after incorporating the views of the four. 
(ii)  Set clear milestones and targets to guide the management, branch managers, and 
bank officials responsible for NPL resolution and launch the plan. Prepare a simple, 
practical manual for NPL resolution, taking into consideration the manual currently 
being used and disseminated. Conduct training sessions at the major branch offices. 
(iii)  Set  implementation  targets  and  monitor  progress.  Where  bottlenecks  are 
encountered, expeditiously provide technical inputs. Prepare a progress report and 
submit  it  to  bank  management,  IBAs,  and  ADB.  Propose  remedial  actions,  if 
necessary, and incorporate them into the plan.  
(iv)  Support  establishment  of  the  legal  department  by  (a)  preparing  a  simple  and 
practical mandate of the division; (b) presenting to bank management a reasonable 
budget proposal for establishing the legal department, and (c) recruiting appropriate 
staff. Ensure operationalization of the legal department during the assignment. 
(v)  Prepare a final report on achievements under the TA (including details on all NPLs 
resolved during the assignment) and follow-up actions.  
(vi)  Review the proposals for a structured voluntary system to allow SOCBs to enforce 
security without recourse to the courts, draft the necessary procedures, and initiate 
the process to implement the system. 
 
7.  Governance and Judicial Training Consultant (domestic, 5 person-months) 
 
12.  The consultant will have a working knowledge of the court system in the Lao PDR and 
some understanding of commercial law, and will coordinate closely with the international consultant. 
The  consultant  will  provide  translation  services  as  required  and  will  assist  with  organizing 
workshops, seminars, and training sessions. Specifically, the domestic consultant will (i) assist the 
international expert in assessing implementation of training undertaken under TA 4002 (footnote 1) 
and provide inputs into the training materials to ensure they are acceptable in the Lao context; (ii) 
act as interpreter in relevant meetings and translator of relevant materials; (iii) monitor progress 
with the set implementation targets during the absence of the international expert and where 
bottlenecks are encountered, contact the international expert to enable expeditious provision of 
technical inputs;  and (iv) provide international expert with data/information needed for preparing all 
training materials, legal documents, and reports to be submitted to MOJ, IAs, and ADB.  
 
8.  Mediation and Arbitration Consultant (domestic, 2.5 person-months) 
 
13.  The consultant will (i) have a working knowledge of alternative dispute mechanisms in the 
Lao PDR and mediation and arbitration processes; (ii) coordinate closely with the international 
mediation consultant; (iii) provide translation services as required; and (iv) assist with organizing 
workshops, seminars, and training sessions. Specifically the domestic consultant will (i) assist the 
international expert in assessing issues impeding progress in mediation and arbitration process for 
preparing materials that will be relevant in the Lao context; (ii) act as interpreter in relevant 
meetings and translator of relevant materials; (iii) monitor progress with the set implementation 
targets during the absence of the international expert; where bottlenecks are encountered, contact 
the international expert to enable expeditious provision of technical inputs; and (iv) provide the 
international  expert  with  data/information  needed  for  preparing  all  training  materials,  legal 
documents and reports to be submitted to MOJ, IAs, and ADB. 
 
9.  Enforcement Consultant (domestic, 2.5 person-months) 
 
14.  The  consultant  will  (i)  have  a  working  knowledge  of  the  enforcement  processes;  (ii) 
coordinate closely with the international consultant; (iii) provide translation services as required;

Appendix 3  13 
and assist with organizing workshops, seminars, and training sessions. Specifically, the domestic 
consultant will (i) assist the international expert in assessing issues impeding progress in judgment 
enforcement and in formulating a tactical plan for accelerating NPL resolution; (ii) act as interpreter 
in  relevant  meetings  and  translator  of  relevant  materials;  (iii)    monitor  progress  with  the  set 
implementation  targets  during  the  absence  of  the  international  expert;  where  bottlenecks  are 
encountered, contact the international expert to enable expeditious provision of technical inputs; 
and (iv) provide the international expert with data/information needed for preparing all training 
materials, legal documents, and reports to be submitted to MOJ, IAs, and ADB.  
 
10.  Legal Expert to Develop Lexicon and Provide Training Support (domestic, 4 
person-months) 
 
15.  The specialist will (i) finalize the consultations and review with Government and private 
sector of the draft legal lexicon (developed under TA 4279); (ii) support the legal expert, the 
secured  transactions  registry  expert,  and  others  under  the  project,  as  required,  in  providing 
detailed input on the laws and regulations on secured transactions, the secured transactions 
implementing decree and other major laws; (ii) implement training workshops as required by the 
international  experts  to  improve  stakeholder  awareness  of  legal  rights  under  the  secured 
transactions registry, and (iii) prepare for consultation meetings between government agencies, the 
consultants, and the private sector to ensure effective use of the registry. 
 
11.  Secured Transactions Registry Expert to Develop Basic Secured Transactions 
Registry (domestic, 6 person-months) 
 
16.  The specialist will work with the secured transactions expert to develop a basic secured 
transactions registry as per the requirements of the Lao commercial banks, line ministries, the 
private sector (including NGOs), and the commercial courts. The specialist will work closely on the 
training  of  the  registry  staff  as  per  the  training  module  developed  in  coordination  with  the 
international secured transactions expert. 
 
12.  NPL Resolution Specialist (domestic, 5 person-months) 
 
17.  The  specialist  will  have  a  legal  banking  sector  background,  preferably  in  a  work 
environment, and solid understanding of bank operations in the Lao PDR; and be knowledgeable 
on issues related to NPL resolution. Moreover, the specialist must have demonstrated ability to (i) 
interface well with Government officials and higher level management of state-owned banks or 
enterprises; (ii) communicate effectively in English; and (iii) be proactive and ensure that the 
project moves according to schedule in the absence of international consultants. Specifically, the 
specialist will (i) assist the international expert in assessing of issues impeding progress in NPL 
resolution at the three SOCBs and in formulating a tactical plan for accelerating NPL resolution; (ii)  
act  as  interpreter  in  relevant  meetings  and  translator  of  relevant  materials;  (iii)  support  the 
international expert in initiating the tactical plan and, in particular, be responsible for translating and 
disseminating the manual for NPL resolution and in making all necessary arrangements for training 
sessions on the manual to be conducted at the major branch offices; (iv) monitor progress with the 
set implementation targets during the absence of the international expert and where bottlenecks 
are encountered, contact the international expert to enable expeditious provision of technical inputs; 
and (v) provide the international expert with data/information needed for preparing all reports to be 
submitted to bank management, IBAs, and ADB.
